causes: The Ashanti Kingdom's resistance to British colonial rule in West Africa
The British attempt to annex the Ashanti Kingdom into the Gold Coast Colony
Cultural and religious significance of the Golden Stool to the Ashanti people
events_leading_up_to_war: The British demand to take possession of the Golden Stool, a sacred artifact and symbol of the Ashanti monarchy
Queen Yaa Asantewaa, the Ashanti regent, leads the defense against British imperialism after the death of the Ashanti king
The British attempt to capture the Ashanti capital, Kumasi, in 1900, sparking full-scale conflict

result.treaty: No formal treaty signed, but the Ashanti Kingdom is effectively annexed
result.territorial_changes: Ashanti Kingdom absorbed into the British Gold Coast Colony

major_battles.name: Battle of Cedi
major_battles.description: Ashanti forces ambushed British troops while they were advancing on the capital, Kumasi.

major_battles.name: Siege of Kumasi
major_battles.description: A prolonged siege in which Ashanti forces, led by Queen Yaa Asantewaa, defend Kumasi against the British invaders.

terms: Ashanti Kingdom formally annexed into the British Gold Coast Colony
Yaa Asantewaa exiled to Seychelles, but she remained a symbol of resistance
impact: Marked the end of major resistance by the Ashanti against British colonial rule
The Golden Stool, a symbol of Ashanti royalty, was never relinquished by the Ashanti people, becoming a symbol of defiance

long_term_effects: Further consolidation of British control over the Gold Coast, which later became Ghana
The Ashanti people continued to resist colonial rule, though this resistance largely ended after 1900

economic: Further expansion of British control over the Gold Coast's resources, particularly gold and cocoa
political: The war solidified the power of the British Empire in West Africa
Marked one of the last major uprisings against colonial rule in the region
social: Increased European dominance in the region, with lingering effects on local traditions and power structures
Queen Yaa Asantewaa became a symbol of African resistance against colonialism
